Subject: Interactive Picture CPPN-Compiler
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=360532607; y=msEv-MZ4o_MRmugsFsPdmPkdPrn8e10r0GRIQyb_bRfNsF-i1wiNMys

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

Hi all,

I'm happy to announce that two of my Master students, Jinhong Zhang and
Rasmus Taarnby, have finished a first version of an interactive Picture
CPPN-Compiler. In this application you can draw an image, then
automatically convert it into a CPPN, and evolve further from there. The
benefit of this system is that you can start evolution from an interesting
part of the image space. You can test the system here:
http://rasmustaarnby.dk/thesis/

This application is based on the concept of a CPPN-Compiler that allows the
user to directly compile a high-level description of a specific image into
the CPPN itself. That way the compiled CPPN directly embodies important
domain regularities (e.g. bilateral symmetric arms), which allows its
offspring to show meaningful
variations that nevertheless share common features.

You can find the original CPPN-Compiler paper here:
http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~risi/risi_aaai2013.pdf

We are looking forward to your comments!

Cheers,
Sebastian

Note: Because we use a self-signed certificate you have to add the page to
your java exception site list in order to run it. Instructions are at the
bottom of this page: http://rasmustaarnby.dk/thesis/how-to/ Also, this is
an early version of the application so there are still some bugs we have to
work out.

--
Dr. Sebastian Risi
Assistant Professor
IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08
Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark
email: sebastian.risi@..., web: www.sebastianrisi.com
mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
